Irish: Bái mesca mór for Ulto fecht n-and i nSliab Fúait. Docuridar didiu immarbága móra ocus comrama eturro .i. etir Chonall ocus Coinculaind ocus Lóegaire. “Tucaid dam-sa” ar Conall “inchind Me[i]ssgegra co ro-acilliur ócu na comram.” Ba bés d’ Ultaib ind inbaid sin cach curaid nomarbdais ar galaib óenfhir nogatta a n-inchind assa cendaib ocus commesct[h]a áel airthib co ndénad líathróite crúade díb. Ocus intan nobítis i n-immarbáig nó chomramaib dobertis dóib co mbítis inna lámaib.
English: Once upon a time the men of Ulster were greatly intoxicated in Sliab Fúait. Thence there arise great contentions and comparison of trophies between them, even between Conall and Cuchulinn and Loegaire. “Bring me,” said Conall, “the brain of Mesgegra, so that I may talk to the competing warriors.” At that time it was a custom with the men of Ulster to take the brains out of the head of every warrior whom they slew in single combat, and to mix lime with them, so that they were made into hard balls. And whenever they were in contention or at comparison of trophies, these were brought to them, so that they had them in their hands.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: There was great drunkenness upon the Ulaid once in Sliab Fúait. Then they engaged in great boastings and contests among them, that is, between Conall and Cú Chulainn and Loegaire. “Give to me,” said Conall, “the brain of Mesgegra, so that I may entertain the youths of the contest.” It was a custom for the Ulaid at that time that every warrior whom they would kill in single combat, they would take their brain out of their heads and mix lime with them so that it would make hard balls of them. And when they would be in a boasting contest or contests, they would give them to them so that they would be in their hands.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: There was great drunkenness upon the Ulstermen one time in Sliab Fúait. Then they engaged in great boastings and contests among themselves, namely between Conall and Cú Chulainn and Loegaire. “Give to me,” said Conall, “the brain of Mess Gegra so that I may address the youths of the contest.” It was a custom for the Ulstermen at that time that every champion whom they would kill in single combat, they would take their brains from their heads and mix lime with them so that it would make hard balls of them. And when they would be in a boasting or contests, they would give them to them so that they would be in their hands.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: There was great drunkenness upon the Ulstermen one time in Sliab Fúait. Then they engaged in great boastings and contests among them, namely between Conall and Cú Chulainn and Lóegaire. “Give to me,” said Conall, “the brain of Mesgegra, so that I may entertain the youths of the contest.” It was a custom for the Ulstermen at that time that from every warrior whom they would kill in single combat, they would take their brains from their heads and mix lime with them so that it would make hard balls of them. And when they would be in a boasting or contests, they would give them to them so that they would be in their hands.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: There was great drunkenness upon the Ulaid one time in Sliab Fúait. Then they began great rivalries and contests among them, namely, between Conall and Cú Chulainn and Láegaire. “Bring to me,” said Conall, “the brain of Messgegra, so that I may address the youths of the contest.” It was a custom for the Ulaid at that time that every champion they killed in single combat, they would take their brains out of their heads and mix lime with them so that hard balls would be made from them. And when they were in rivalries or contests, they would be given to them to hold in their hands.

Irish: “Maith, a Conall,” ar Chonchobuir, “na co ndernat óic na comram écht fón innas-[s]a ar galaib óinfhir, nídat túalngi comram frim-sa.” “Is fir ón,” ar Conall.
English: “Well, O Conall,” said Chonchobuir, “until the competing warriors perform a deed like this in single combat, they are not capable of comparing trophies with me.” “That is true,” said Conall.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: “Well, Conall,” said Conchobar, “until young men perform the mighty feat in this manner, by the prowess of a single man, they are not capable of combat against me.” “That is true,” said Conall.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: “Well, Conall,” said Conchobar, “unless young men perform a deed of slaughter in this manner by the prowess of a single man, they are not capable of combat against me.” “That is true,” said Conall.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Well, Conall,' said Conchobar, 'unless young men perform these heroic deeds in this manner by single combat, they are not capable of fighting me.' 'That is true,' said Conall.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: “Well, Conall,” said Conchobar, “unless young warriors perform such a feat of slaughter in this manner by single combat, they are not able to contend with me.” “That is true,” said Conall.

Irish: Doratad íarum forsin forud fora mbíd dogrés ind inchind. Luid cách a lethi arnabárach dia cluchiu. Dolluid dano Cet mac Matach do chúairt ectra la Ulto. Béist ass andsam robói i nHérinn in Cet. Ised dolluid-side dar faidchi na hFúait  ocus tri láechcind leis do Ultaib.
English: Then the brain was put upon the shelf upon which it was always kept. On the morrow every one went his own way to his sport. Then Cet, the son of Matu, went upon a round of adventures in Ulster. This Cet was the most troublesome pest that was in Ireland. This is the way he went, across the green of Fúait , having with him three warriors’ heads of the men of Ulster.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then the brain was placed on the dais where it always was. The next day, everyone went their own way to their games. Then Cet mac Matach came on a raiding expedition among the Ulaid. Cet was the most formidable monster in Ireland. He came across the plain of Fúait, and with him were three warrior-heads of the Ulaid.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Then the brain was placed on the dais where it always was. The next day, everyone went their separate ways to their games. Then Cet son of Matach came on an expedition among the Ulaid. This Cet was the fiercest monster that was in Ireland. It was thus that he came across the plain of Fúait with three warrior-heads of the Ulaid.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then the brain was placed upon the stand where it always used to be. Everyone went their separate ways the next day to their game. Then Cet son of Matach came on an expedition among the Ulaid. Cet was the fiercest beast that was in Ireland. He came across the green of Fúait with three warrior-heads of the Ulaid.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then the brain was placed on the platform where it always used to be. The next day everyone went their separate ways to their games. Then Cet son of Matach came on an expedition among the Ulaid. Cet was the fiercest beast that was in Ireland. Thus he came across the plain of Fúait with three warrior-heads of the Ulaid.

Irish: Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib.
English: Once then Cet went eastwards until he took a drove of cows from the men of the Rosses. The men of Ulster overtook him in pursuit after him. Then the men of Connaught came up from the other side to rescue him. A battle is fought between them. Conall himself went into the battle. And it was then that the women of Connaught begged Conall to come aside so that they might see his shape. For there was not on earth the shape of a human being like the shape of Conchobar, both for beauty and figure and dress, for size and symmetry and proportion, for eye and hair and whiteness, for wisdom and manners and eloquence, for raiment and nobleness and equipment, for weapons and wealth and dignity, for bearing and valour and race. That Conall was faultless indeed. However, it was by the advice of Cet that the women importuned Conchobar. Then he went aside alone to be seen by the women.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: On one occasion then, Cet came eastwards and brought a cattle raid from the Men of Ross. The Ulstermen pursued him and caught up with him. Then the Connachtmen came from the other side to rescue him. A battle was fought between them. Conchobar himself came into the battle. And it was then that the women of Connacht begged Conall to go aside to see his form for them. Because there was not on earth the form of a man like the form of Conchobar, namely, in shape and form and raiment, in size and proportion and symmetry, in eye and hair and fairness, in wisdom and custom and eloquence, in attire and splendor and appearance, in arms and multitude and dignity, in demeanor and valor and lineage. Conall was not at fault then. However, by Cet's counsel, the women made a request concerning Conchobar. He then went aside alone to see him for the women.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Once, Cet came east and brought a cattle raid from the Men of Ross. The Ulstermen overtook him in pursuit. Then the Connachta came from the other side to rescue him. A battle was fought between them. Conchobar himself entered the battle. It was then that the women of Connacht asked Conall to step aside so they could see his form. For there was not on earth the form of a man like Conchobar's form, that is, in form and figure and raiment, in size and proportion and symmetry, in eye and hair and fairness, in wisdom and custom and speech, in attire and splendour and bearing, in arms and abundance and dignity, in nature and valour and lineage. Conall was not at fault then. However, on Cet's advice, the women made a request to Conchobar. He then went aside alone to be seen by the women.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: On one occasion, Cet came eastward and took a drove of cattle from the Men of Ross. The Ulstermen pursued him and overtook him. Then the Connachta came from the other side to rescue him. A battle was fought between them. Conchobar himself entered the battle. It was then that the women of Connacht asked Conall to step aside so they might see his (Conchobar's) form. For there was not on earth the form of a man like Conchobar's form, that is, in shape and figure and raiment, in size and proportion and symmetry, in eye and hair and fairness, in wisdom and custom and eloquence, in attire and splendor and appearance, in weapon and abundance and dignity, in custom and valor and lineage. Conall was not to blame then. However, it was by Cet's counsel that the women made the request concerning Conchobar. He then went aside alone to be seen by the women.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then on one occasion, Cet came eastward and brought a cattle raid from the Men of Ross. The Ulaid overtook him in pursuit. Then the Connachta came from the other side to rescue him. A battle was fought between them. Conchobar himself came into the battle. So it was then that the women of Connacht begged Conall that Conchobar should step aside for them to see his form. Because there was not on earth the form of a man like Conchobar's form, that is, both in appearance and figure and attire, both in size and proportion and symmetry, both in eye and hair and fairness, both in wisdom and character and speech, both in array and splendor and bearing, both in arms and magnificence and dignity, both in nature and valor and lineage. Conall indeed was not at fault. However, it was Cet's advice that the women followed in their desire for Conchobar. He then went aside by himself to be seen by the women.

Irish: Dolluid Cet immorro co mbúi etir na mná immedón. Nosindlethar Cet inchind Mesgegra isin tábaill ocus nosteilc conidtarla immullach Conall co mbátar a dá trían inna chind ocus co torchairseom isa cend, co tarla fri lár. Focherddat Ulaid chuci conidrucsat ó Chet. For brú Átha Daire Dá Báeth is and dorochair Conall. Atá a lige and baile i torchair ocus corthe fria chend ocus corthe fria chossa.
English: Cet, however, went until he was in the midst of the women. He adjusts the brain of Mesgegra in the sling, and throws it so that it hit the crown of Conall’s head, so that two-thirds of it entered his head, so that he fell upon his head forward to the ground. The men of Ulster ran towards him, and carried him off from Cet. On the brink of the ford of Daire Dá Báeth it was that Conall fell. His grave is there where he fell, and a pillar-stone at his head, and another at his feet.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Cét came then, so that he was among the women in the middle. Cét brandishes Mes Gegra's brain in his hand and throws it so that it struck Conall on the forehead, and two-thirds of it were in his head, and he fell headlong to the ground. The Ulstermen rushed to him and carried him away from Cét. On the bank of Áth Daire Dá Báeth, there Conall fell. His grave is there where he fell, with a pillar-stone at his head and a pillar-stone at his feet.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Cét came, moreover, and was in the midst of the women. Cét threw Mesgegra's brain in the sling and cast it so that it struck Conall on the crown of his head, and two-thirds of it went into his head, and he fell headlong, striking the ground. The Ulstermen rushed to him and carried him away from Cét. Conall fell there on the bank of Áth Daire Dá Báeth. His grave is there where he fell, with a pillar-stone at his head and a pillar-stone at his feet.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Cet came, moreover, and was in the midst of the women. Cet brandishes Mesgegra's brain in the sling and casts it so that it struck Conall's crown, so that two-thirds of it were in his head, and he fell headlong, so that he struck the ground. The Ulstermen rushed to him and carried him away from Cet. It is on the bank of Áth Daire Dá Báeth that Conall fell. His grave is there where he fell, with a pillar-stone at his head and a pillar-stone at his feet.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Cet, moreover, came and was among the women in the middle. Cet swung Mesgegra's brain-ball in the sling and cast it so that it struck Conall on the crown of his head, and two-thirds of it lodged in his head, and he fell headlong, hitting the ground. The Ulstermen rushed to him and carried him away from Cet. It was on the bank of Áth Daire Dá Báeth that Conall fell. His grave is there where he fell, with a pillar stone at his head and a pillar stone at his feet.

Irish: Maidid tra for Crích Ross  co Sciaig Aird na Con. Dobertar Ulaid sair doridisi co Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “Mo brith-se ass!” ar Conall. “Dobér ríge nUlad do neoch nombéra connici mo thech.” “Notbér-sa,” ar Cend Berraide, ar a gilla fadéin. Dobeir-side lomain imme ocus nombeir for a muin co Arddachad Emain Macha. Maidid a chride isin gillu. Conid de sin atá ‘ríge Cind Berraide for Ultaib’ .i. in rí for a muin leth ind lái.
English: The men of Crích Ross are then routed to Scé Aird na Con. The men of Ulster are driven eastwards again to the ford of Daire Dá Báeth. “Let me be carried out of this!” said Conall. “I shall give the kingship of Ulster to anyone who will carry me as far as my house.” “I will carry thee,” said Cenn Berraide, his own attendant. He puts a cord around him and carries him upon his back to Ardachad of the Emain Macha . The attendant’s heart broke within him. Hence is the saying over Ulster,’ ‘Cenn Berraide’s kingship over Ulster,’ to wit, the king upon his back for (only ) half the day.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then they advanced over Crích Ross to Sciaig Ard na Con. The Ulstermen were brought eastwards again to Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “Carry me out!” said Conall. “I will give the kingship of Ulster to anyone who will carry me as far as my house.” “I will carry you,” said Cend Berraide, his own servant. He took a burden upon himself and carried him on his back to Arddachad of Emain Macha. The servant's heart broke. So it is from that that 'the kingship of Cend Berraide over the Ulstermen' exists, that is, the king on his back for half the day.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It then extends over Crích Ross to Sciaig Ard na Con. The Ulstermen are brought east again to Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'Carry me out of here!' said Conall. 'I will give the kingship of Ulster to anyone who will carry me as far as my house.' 'I will carry you,' said Cend Berraide, his own servant. He puts a strap around him and carries him on his back to Arddachad of Emain Macha. His heart breaks in the servant. And from that comes 'the kingship of Cend Berraide over the Ulstermen', that is, the king on his back for half the day.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then a rout breaks out over Crích Ross as far as Sciaig Ard na Con. The Ulstermen are brought east again to Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'Carry me out!' said Conall. 'I will give the kingship of Ulster to whoever carries me to my house.' 'I will carry you,' said Cend Berraide, his own gillie. He puts a strap on himself and carries him on his back to Arddachad of Emain Macha. The gillie's heart breaks. And from that comes 'the kingship of Cend Berraide over the Ulstermen', that is, the king on his back for half the day.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then it proceeds over Crích Ross to Sciaig Ard na Con. The Ulaid are brought east again to Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “Take me out of here!” said Conall. “I will give the kingship of the Ulaid to whoever carries me as far as my house.” “I will carry you,” said Cend Berraide, his own servant. He puts a strap around himself and carries him on his back to Ardachad Emain Macha. His heart breaks in the lad. And it is from that that ‘the kingship of Cend Berraide over the Ulaid’ exists, namely, the king on his back for half the day.

Irish: Conócbad trá in debaid ón tráth co araile dar éis in ríg. Co ráimid for Ulto íarsin.
English: However, the fight was kept up after the king from one hour of the day to the same hour on the next day, after which the men of Ulster were routed.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The conflict, then, would be maintained from time to time after the king. And it fell upon the Ulaid thereafter.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The conflict would then be stirred up from time to time after the king, and then it broke out upon the Ulaid.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The strife, then, was maintained from time to time after the king. And it broke out against the Ulaid thereafter.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The dispute was then kept up from time to time after the king. And it fell upon the Ulstermen thereafter.

Irish: Doberar tra a liaig co Conall .i. Fingen. Iss éside nofhinnad don díaid nothéiged don tig in lín nobíd i ngalur ’sin tig ocus cech galar nobíd and. “Maith,” or Fingen, “dia taltar in chloch as do chind biat marb fo chétóir. Mani tucthar ass immorro, not-ícfaind ocus bid athis duit.” “Is asso dún” ar Ulaid “ind athis oldás a éc som.”
English: In the meantime his physician was brought to Conall, even Fingen. ’Tis he who would know from the smoke that arose from a house how many were ill in the house, and every disease that was in it. “Well,” said Fingen, “if the stone is taken out of thy head, thou wilt be dead forthwith. If it is not taken out, however, I would heal thee, but it will be a blemish for thee.” “It is easier for us,” said the men of Ulster, “to bear the blemish than his death.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then his physician, namely Fingen, is brought to Conall. It was he who would know from the smoke that went to the house the number of people who were sick in the house and every disease that was there. “Well,” said Fingen, “if the stone is taken out of your head, you will be dead immediately. If it is not taken out, however, I would heal you, and it would be a disgrace to you.” “The disgrace is easier for us,” said the Ulstermen, “than his death.”
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Then his physician, Fingen, was brought to Conall. It was he who, from the smoke that entered the house, would know the number of people sick within and every disease present. 'Well,' said Fingen, 'if the stone is removed from your head, you will die immediately. If it is not removed, however, I would heal you, but it would be a disgrace to you.' 'The disgrace is easier for us,' said the Ulaid, 'than his death.'
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then his physician, Fingen, was brought to Conall. It was he who, from the vapor that went to the house, would discover the number of people who were sick in the house and every disease that was there. “Well,” said Fingen, “if the stone is taken out of your head, you will be dead immediately. If it is not taken out, however, I would heal you, and it would be a disgrace for you.” “The disgrace is easier for us,” said the Ulstermen, “than his death.”
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then his physician, Fingen, is brought to Conall. He was the one who, from the fumes that would enter the house, would determine the number of people who were ill in the house and every illness that was there. “Well,” said Fingen, “if the stone is extracted from your head, you will be dead immediately. If it is not extracted, however, I would heal you, and it would be a disgrace for you.” “The disgrace is easier for us,” said the Ulaid, “than his death.”

Irish: Ro-íccad íarum a chend ocus rofúaged co snáth óir, ar ba cumma dath fuilt Conchobuir ocus dath inn óir. Ocus asbert in liaig fri Conall co mbeth i fomtin .i. ar ná tísad a fherg dó ocus ná digsed for ech ocus ná etraiged mnái [ocus ná rocaithed biad] co anfeta ocus ná rethed.
English: His head was then healed; and it was stitched with thread of gold, for the colour of Conall’s hair was the same as the colour of gold. And the physician said to Conall that he should be on his guard lest anger should come on him, and that he should not mount a horse, that he should not have connexion with a woman, that he should not eat food greedily, and that he should not run.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: His head was then treated and sewn with a gold thread, for the color of Conchobar's hair was the same as the color of the gold. And the physician told Conall to be cautious, that is, lest his rage come upon him, and that he should not ride a horse, nor lie with a woman, nor eat food immoderately, nor run.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Then his head was healed and sewn with gold thread, for the color of Conchobar's hair was the same as the color of the gold. And the physician told Conall to be cautious, that is, lest his anger come upon him, and that he should not ride a horse, and that he should not lie with a woman, and that he should not eat food immoderately, and that he should not run.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: His head was then healed and sewn with a thread of gold, for the colour of Conchobar's hair was the same as the colour of the gold. And the physician said to Conall that he should be cautious, that is, lest his rage should come upon him, and that he should not ride a horse, nor lie with a woman, nor eat food immoderately, nor run.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: His head was then healed and stitched with golden thread, for the color of Conchobar's hair and the color of the gold were the same. And the physician told Conall that he should be at rest, namely, lest his anger come upon him, and that he should not ride a horse, nor lie with a woman, nor eat food immoderately, nor run.

Irish: Robói dano isin chuntabairt sin céin robo beó .i. secht mbliadna ocus nírbo engnamaid, acht a airisium inna shuidi nammá .i. naco cúala Críst do chrochad do Iudaidib. Tánic and side crith mór forsna dúli ocus rochrithnaig nem ocus talam la mét in gníma darónad and  .i. Ísu Críst mac Dé bí do chrochad cen chinaid. “Cráet so?” ar Conall fria drúid. “Cia olc mór dogníther isind lathiu-sa indiú?” “Is fir ón ém,” ar in drúi. “Is mór in gním sin,” ar Conall. “In fer sin dano” ar in drúi “i n-óenaidchi rogein ocus rogenis-[s]iu .i. i n-ocht calde Enair cen cop inund bliadain.”
English: In that doubtful state, then, he was as long as he lived, even seven years; and he was not capable of action, but remained in his seat only, until he heard that Christ had been crucified by the Jews. At that time a great trembling came over the elements, and the heavens and the earth shook with the enormity of the deed that was then done, even Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God, to be crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to his druid. “What great evil is being done on this day?” “That is true, indeed,” said the druid [who then tells the story of the Crucifixion ]. “Awful is that deed,” said Conall. “That man, now,” said the druid, “was born in the same night in which thou wast born, even on the eighth before the calends of January, though the year was not the same.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: He remained in that state of doubt as long as he lived, that is, for seven years, and he was not active, but only stayed in his seat, until he heard that Christ had been crucified by the Jews. Then a great trembling came upon the elements, and heaven and earth quaked at the magnitude of the deed that was done there, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of the living God, crucified without sin. “What is this?” said Conall to his druid. “What great evil is being done on this day today?” “That is true indeed,” said the druid. “That is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man then,” said the druid, “was born on the same night as you were born, that is, on the eighth kalends of January, though not in the same year.”
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: He was then in that doubt as long as he lived, that is, seven years, and he was not active, but only remained in his seat, until he heard Christ was crucified by the Jews. Then a great trembling came upon the elements, and heaven and earth trembled at the greatness of the deed that was done there, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of the living God, crucified without guilt. 'What is this?' said Conall to his druid. 'What great evil is being done on this day today?' 'That is true indeed,' said the druid. 'That is a great deed,' said Conall. 'That man then,' said the druid, 'was born on the same night as you were born, that is, on the eighth kalends of January, though not in the same year.'
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: He remained then in that doubt as long as he lived, that is, seven years, and he was inactive, but only remained in his seat, that is, until he heard that Christ had been crucified by the Jews. Then a great trembling came upon the elements, and heaven and earth trembled at the magnitude of the deed that was done there, that is, Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God, crucified without sin. 'What is this?' said Conall to his druid. 'What great evil is being done on this day?' 'That is truly so,' said the druid. 'That is a great deed,' said Conall. 'That man then,' said the druid, 'was born on the same night that you were born, that is, on the eighth kalends of January, though not in the same year.'
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: He was then in that doubt as long as he lived, that is, seven years, and he was not active, but only remained in his seat, until he heard Christ being crucified by the Jews. Then a great trembling came upon the elements, and heaven and earth trembled at the greatness of the deed that was done there, that is, Jesus Christ, Son of the living God, being crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to his druid. “What great evil is being done this day?” “That is true indeed,” said the druid. “That is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man then,” said the druid, “was born on the same night that you were born, that is, on the eighth calends of January, though not in the same year.”

Irish: Is andsin rochreiti Conall. Ocus issé sin indara fer rochreti do Día i nHérinn ría tiachtain creitmi é .i. Morand in fer aile.
English: It was then that Conall believed. And he was one of the two men that had believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the Faith, Morann being the other man.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It was then that Conall believed. And he was the second man who believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the faith, the other being Morand.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It was then that Conall believed. And he was one of the two men who believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the faith, that is, Morand was the other man.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then Conall believed. And he was the second man who believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the Faith, the other being Morann.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then Conall believed. And he was the second man who believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the Faith, that is, Morand was the other man.

Irish: Ocus as iarsin asbert Conall: “Rofeasdais fir in beatha mo cumang ac cathugud fri hIudaidhibh tre crochad Críst dia mbeinn a comfogus dó.” Is iarsin attraacht ocus rosgobh forsin deargail cur’sceinn incinn Mesgeagra as a cinn ocus conearbailt Concubur fochétóir. Conadh [d]esin adber[a]t na Gæidhil conadh hé Concubur cétgeinntlide docóidh docum neimhi a nÉirinn, fobíth robo baithis dó in fuil dobidg as[a] cinn. Et as annsin rucadh ainim Conall a n ifrinn gu comraiced Críst fria ac te:uir na broide a hifrinn, co tuc Críst leis anim Conall docum neimhi. Finid.
English: And thereupon Conall said: “The men of the world would know what I can do in fighting against the Jews for the sake of the crucifixion of Christ, if I were near Him.” Then he rose and made the onslaught, until Mesgegra’s brains jumped out of his head, so that Conall died forthwith. Hence the Gaels say that Conall was the first pagan who went to Heaven in Ireland, for the blood that sprang out of his head was a baptism to him. And then Conall’s soul was taken to hell until Christ encountered her as He brought the captive host out of hell, so that Christ took the soul of Conall with Him to Heaven. Finit.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: And then Conall said: “The men of the world would know my power in fighting against the Jews on account of Christ’s crucifixion, if I were near him.” Then he rose and struck the red-hot mass so that Mesgeagra’s brain burst from his head, and Conchobar died immediately. So it is from this that the Gaels say that Conchobar was the first pagan who went to heaven in Ireland, because the blood that spurted from his head was a baptism for him. And then Conall’s soul was taken to hell until Christ met him when taking the captives from hell, so Christ took Conall’s soul with him to heaven. End.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: And then Conall said: “The men of the world would know my power fighting against the Jews because of the crucifixion of Christ, if I were near him.” Then he arose and struck him with the brain-ball, so that Mesgegra's brain burst from his head, and Conchobar died immediately. So for this reason the Gaels say that Conchobar was the first pagan who went to heaven in Ireland, because the blood that spurted from his head was a baptism for him. And then Conall's soul was taken to hell until Christ met him when taking the captives from hell, so Christ took Conall's soul with him to heaven. End.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: And then Conall said: “The men of the world would know my power in fighting against the Jews for the crucifixion of Christ, if I were near him.” Then he rose up and struck with the brain-ball so that Mesgegra's brain burst from his head and Concubur died immediately. Therefore, the Gaels say that Concubur was the first pagan to go to heaven in Ireland, because the blood that spurted from his head was a baptism for him. And then Conall's soul was taken to hell until Christ met him when taking the captives from hell, so that Christ took Conall's soul with him to heaven. End.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: And then Conall said: 'The men of the world would know my power in fighting against the Jews because of the crucifixion of Christ, if I were near him.' Then he rose and struck the brain-ball so that Mesgegra's brain burst from his head, and Conchobar died immediately. Therefore the Gaels say that Conchobar was the first heathen who went to heaven in Ireland, because the blood that spurted from his head was a baptism for him. And then Conall's soul was carried to hell until Christ met it when taking the captives from hell, so that Christ took Conall's soul with him to heaven. The End.

Irish: Intan bátar na ónmite ’co cluchiu do inchind Me[i]sgegra, issed atbert ind ónmit fri araile. Rocluinedar Cet aní sin. Ethaid side in n-inchind al-láim indala n-ái ocus berid leiss, ó rofitir Cet robói i tarngere do Messgegra a dígail iarna écaib. Cach cath ocus cach irga[l] nobíd do Chonnachtaib fri Ulto dobered Cet in n-inchind inna chriss dús in tetarthad écht n-amra d’ Ultaib do marbad di.
English: While the jesters (of Emain ) were at play with the brain of Mesgegra, this is what one jester said to the other. Cet hears that. He snatches the brain out of the hand of one of them, and carries it off; for he knew that it had been foretold of Mesgegra that he would avenge himself after his death. In every battle and in every combat which the men of Connaught had with those of Ulster, Cet used to carry the brain in his girdle to see whether he could compass a famous deed by slaying a man of Ulster with it.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: When the fools were playing with Mesgegra's brain, one fool said this to another. Cet heard that. He took the brain from the hand of one of them and carried it with him, for Cet knew there was a prophecy for Mesgegra's vengeance after his death. Every battle and every conflict the Connachtmen had against the Ulstermen, Cet would carry the brain in his belt to see if he could kill a famous Ulsterman with it.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: When the fools were playing with Mesgegra's brain, one fool said this to another. Cet heard that. He took the brain from the hand of one of them and carried it with him, because Cet knew there was a prophecy for Mesgegra of his vengeance after his death. Every battle and every conflict that the Connachta had against the Ulaid, Cet would carry the brain in his belt to see if he could achieve a famous killing of the Ulaid by means of it.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: When the fools were playing with Mesgegra's brain, one fool said to another. Cet heard that. He took the brain from the hand of one of them and carried it with him, for Cet knew that Mesgegra was destined for vengeance after his death. Every battle and every fight that the Connachta had against the Ulaid, Cet would put the brain in his belt to see if he could achieve a wondrous killing among the Ulaid with it.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: While the jesters were playing with Mesgegra's brain, one jester said to another. Cet heard that. He snatched the brain from the hand of one of them and carried it away with him, for Cet knew that Mesgegra's vengeance was foretold after his death. Every battle and every conflict the Connachta had against the Ulstermen, Cet would carry the brain in his belt to see if he might inflict a notable slaying on an Ulsterman with it.

Irish: Loích ro bátar do Mumab .i. Mac Connaid ocus Marrcán ocus Óengus. Is de ro chét: Ní thaet didiu de in cocad fri hOssairge, cen Mac Connaid for eoch án, cen Marccán, cen Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin ro bí in fer isi[nd] móin; túirid na cholaind aile nícon rubae oenguine. Comaithig immorro do Óengus Huí Máil ocus ba holc immorro a chomaithcess doib. Is de ro chét: Huí Máil trícha cét ba hed a lín; nocon fhárgaib Óengus acht trí nónburu díb. A n-as·rubart fodessin: “Is cumma lim-sa huí Máil ocus muilenn oc blith gráin; it fáilte huí Máil fria nguin is cóir cach bró fria tuarcain.”
English: Mac Connaid, Marrcán and Óengus were three warriors of the men of Munster. It was sung of them: From Osraige our warband does not return without Mac Connaid on his noble horse, without Marrcán or Óengus. Óengus descendant of Dímmae Crón killed a man in the marsh: search his whole body for not one wound has struck him. Now Óengus’s neighbours were the Uí Máil and his neighbourship was bad indeed for them. Concerning this it was sung: The Uí Máil, three thousand were their number: Óengus left none but three times nine among them. Óengus himself said: “The Uí Máil and a mill grinding grain are both the same to me. the Uí Máil are welcome to the killings for every quern is proper for crushing.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Warriors of Munster were Mac Connaid, Marrcán, and Óengus. Of this it was sung: The war against Ossory will not cease without Mac Connaid on a splendid horse, without Marrcán, without Óengus. Óengus grandson of Dimmae Cróin killed the man in the bog; the rest of the bodies did not kill anyone. The Uí Máil were neighbours to Óengus, and their neighbourhood was bad for them. Of this it was sung: The Uí Máil, a host of three thousand was their number; Óengus left of them only three nines. What he himself said: 'The Uí Máil are to me like a mill grinding grain; the Uí Máil are eager for their wounding, it is right for every millstone to be struck.'
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Warriors of Munster were Mac Connaid and Marrcán and Óengus. Of this it was sung: The war against Ossory will not cease, without Mac Connaid on a splendid horse, without Marrcán, without Óengus. Óengus grandson of Dimmae Cróin killed the man in the bog; the rest of the company did not inflict a single wound. The Uí Máil were neighbors to Óengus, and their neighborhood was bad for them. Of this it was sung: The Uí Máil, three thousand was their number; Óengus left of them only twenty-seven men. What he himself said: 'The Uí Máil are to me like a mill grinding grain; the Uí Máil are welcome to their slaughter, every millstone is right for pounding.'
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Warriors of Munster were Mac Connaid, Marrcán, and Óengus. It was from this that it was sung: 'The war against Ossory will not then cease, without Mac Connaid on a splendid horse, without Marccán, without Óengus.' Óengus grandson of Dimma Cróin killed the man in the bog; the rest of the company did not inflict a single wound. Moreover, the Uí Máil were neighbors to Óengus, and their neighborhood was bad for them. It was from this that it was sung: 'The Uí Máil, three thousand was their number; Óengus left only twenty-seven of them.' What he himself said: 'The Uí Máil are the same to me as a mill grinding grain; the Uí Máil are welcome to their slaughter, it is right for every millstone to be struck.'
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Warriors who were of Munster, namely Mac Connaid, Marrcán, and Óengus. Of this was sung: The war against Ossory will not cease without Mac Connaid on a splendid horse, without Marrcán, without Óengus. Óengus grandson of Dimmae Crón killed the man in the bog; as for the other bodies, he did not kill anyone else. The Uí Máil, moreover, were neighbours to Óengus, and their neighbourliness was bad for them. Of this was sung: The Uí Máil, a host of three thousand, that was their number; Óengus left of them but three nines. What he himself said: 'The Uí Máil are to me like a mill grinding grain; the Uí Máil are eager for their slaying, every millstone is fit for striking.'

Irish: Athechda rí hua Máil immorro. Do·fuc Óengus a ingin. Luid-si didiu fecht do thig a [h]athar do chomfhis a mmáthar bae i ngalur. Ro aslacht a hathair fuirri-se brathtecosc a fir dó. “Maith,” ar [in] ben, “fil mo dáil-se fris i-nnocht. Acht a·taat teora huarbotha lais ocus ní fetar-sa ciasu adba díb i fifa i-nnocht, acht ro·fetar-sa a n-as maith duib. Tucthar lib lán mo chlera-sa do thenid sinnaig ocus at·bér-sa is é m’étach-sa fil ann ocus biat-sa ina diaid et láifet-sa in tenid im diaid, ocus toít-si iarmo shlicht.”
English: Now Aithechda was the king of the Uí Máil. Óengus married his daughter. Once she went to the house of her father to visit her mother, who was sick. Her father persuaded her that it was fitting to betray Óengus . “That is good,” said the woman, “I am meeting with him tonight. There are three huts near him and I do not know in which of them he will sleep during the night but I know the best course for you. Bring my bag full of fox-fire and I will tell him that my dress is inside it: I will follow after him, then you throw the fox-fire behind me and follow in my path.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Now, Athechda was king of Uí Máil. Aengus married his daughter. She then went once to her father's house to visit her mother, who was ill. Her father urged her to give him treacherous instruction concerning her husband. 'Well,' said the woman, 'I have an appointment with him tonight. But he has three cold huts, and I do not know in which of them he will sleep tonight, but I do know what is good for you. Bring with you the full of my cloak of fox-fire, and I will say that it is my clothing that is there, and I will be after it, and I will scatter the fire after me, and it will follow its track.'
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Now, there was a daughter of the king of Uí Máil. Óengus married her. She went one time to her father's house to inquire about her mother, who was ill. Her father urged her to betray her husband to him. “Good,” said the woman, “I have a meeting with him tonight. But he has three cold dwellings, and I do not know in which of them he will sleep tonight, but I do know what is good for you. Let the full of my basket of fox-fire be brought by you, and I will say that it is my clothing that is there, and I will be after it, and I will throw the fire behind me, and let it follow its track.”
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Athechda was king of Uí Máil. Aengus married his daughter. She went once to her father's house to inquire about her mother, who was ill. Her father urged her to betray her husband's secrets to him. 'Good,' said the woman, 'I have an appointment with him tonight. But he has three cold dwellings, and I do not know in which of them he will sleep tonight, but I know what is good for you. Bring with you the full of my basket of foxfire, and I will say that it is my clothing that is there, and I will be after it, and I will throw the fire after me, and it will fall along its track.'
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Now there was a king of Uí Máil. Óengus had taken his daughter. So she went once to her father’s house to inquire about her mother, who was ill. Her father urged her to give him a treacherous instruction about her husband. “Good,” said the woman, “I have an appointment with him tonight. But he has three cold huts, and I do not know which dwelling of them he will sleep in tonight, but I do know what is good for you. Let the full of my cloak of foxfire be brought with you, and I will say that it is my clothing which is there, and I will be after it, and I will cast the fire after me, and it will fall following its trace.”

Irish: Ba fír ón. Tiagait co mbátar immun n-uarboith. Con·gairet fair. “Innat-fhail tall, a Oengus?” “Cosmail mo bith,” ar Óengus, “ocus ná marbaid for siair. Nos léicebh chucaib.” “Mo chen di,” ar ind óic. La sodain lomraid a c(h)ennchongraim na mmná ocus do·beir immo chenn fesin ocus luid secco samlaid. “Robbar bia imned,” ar ei-sseom, “i-fecht-sa lim-sa. Mo ben-sa ocus for n-ingen féin ro marbsaid.” Ocus ros fuabair coro lá a n-ár in tan sin. Do·gní iarum Óengus ocus Aithechda córai dib línaib.
English: So it happened. [The sons of Aithechda] went until they were near the hut and they called to him,  “Are you there, Óengus?” “It is likely that I am,” he replied. “Do not kill your sister:  I shall allow her to come out to you.” “That is well with us,” the young men said. With that Óengus stripped the shawl from the woman, put it about his own head and so made his way past them. *With that, they attacked the hut and killed the person inside it. Then he called from behind them: “I will make you regret that now,” he said. “You have killed my wife and your own sister.”* Then he set upon the men and slaughtered them. Afterwards Óengus and Aithechda made peace.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: That was so. They went until they were around the cold hut. They called to him. “Are you there, Oengus?” “It is likely I am,” said Oengus, “and do not kill your sister. I will let her go to you.” “Welcome to her,” said the youths. With that, he shaved the woman's head-dress and put it around his own head and went past them like that. “You will have trouble,” said he, “this time with me. My wife and your own daughter you have killed.” And he attacked them so that he slaughtered them at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made peace between them both.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: That was true. They went until they were around the cold hut. They called out to him. “Are you in there, Oengus?” “It is likely I am,” said Oengus, “and do not kill your sister. I will release her to you.” “Welcome her,” said the youths. With that he shaved the woman's head-covering and put it around his own head and went past them like that. “You will have trouble,” said he, “now with me. My wife and your own daughter you have killed.” And he attacked them so that he slew them at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made peace between them both.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: That was true. They went until they were around the cold hut. They called to him. 'Are you there, Oengus?' 'It is likely that I am,' said Oengus, 'and do not kill your sister. I will let her go to you.' 'Welcome her,' said the youths. With that, he shaved the woman's hair and put it around his own head and went past them like that. 'You will have trouble,' said he, 'this time with me. My wife and your own daughter you have killed.' And he attacked them so that he made a slaughter of them at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made peace between them both.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: That was true. They went until they were around the cold hut. They called out to him. “Are you there, Oengus?” “It is likely that I am,” said Oengus, “and do not kill your sister. I will let her go to you.” “Welcome to her,” said the youths. With that, he shaved the woman's hair and put it around his own head and passed by thus. “Trouble will befall you,” said he, “this time from me. My own wife and your own daughter you have killed.” And he attacked them so that he slaughtered them at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made peace between them both.

Irish: tánaic in chaillech reimpi co Colmán ocus ro ghab in rann do:— “A Colmán in imráidi . imghlasad iar nimbáini? seis duit t’aenarán cin nech . in núir aidhne” “A mendocán imráidim . ocus dna cáin innláidim; cech aen [dar] ráinic a les . ní dechaid cin domainches” “Is é mo domainchessa” ar sí “m’aenmhacán.” “fogabasa sin dana” or Colmán “ocus digéltair sin for Aena.”
English: The old woman went straight to Colmán, and sang the quatrain at him, thus:— “Considerest thou, Colmán, the turning livid that follows the first mere growing pale? be certified of this: that all alone and without a fellow thou shalt yet dwell under mould of aidhne” *Said Colmán:— “I think of it often enough, and, indeed, my indulgence is that anyone who needs relief, will not go away without their petition being granted.”* She went on: “my petition is for my only little son”; and Colmán answered: “thou shalt have him, *indeed,* but Aena shall be avenged for this.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The hag came forward to Colmán and recited the verse to him: “O Colmán, do you consider the greening after the fading? You sit alone without anyone in the hour of judgment.” “O little monk, I consider it, and indeed I apply it well; everyone who had a need did not go without a deep bond.” “My deep bond,” said she, “is my only son.” “I have found that indeed,” said Colmán, “and that will be avenged upon Aena.”
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The hag came forward to Colmán and recited the verse to him: 'O Colmán, do you consider the greening after the fading? You sit alone without anyone in the fresh earth of Aidhne.' 'O little monk, I do consider it, and indeed I arrange things well; everyone who needed it did not go without a close connection.' 'My close connection,' she said, 'is my only son.' 'I will find that indeed,' said Colmán, 'and that will be avenged on Aena.'
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The old woman came forward to Colmán and recited the verse to him: “O Colmán, do you consider the greening after the whitening? You sit alone without anyone in the earth of Aidhne.” “O little monk, I consider it, and indeed I set things in order; everyone who needed it did not go without a deep bond.” “My deep bond,” said she, “is my only son.” “I understand that now,” said Colmán, “and that will be avenged on Aena.”
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The hag came to Colmán and recited the verse to him:— 'O Colmán, do you meditate on turning green after becoming pale? You sit alone without anyone in the fresh earth.' 'O little mendicant, I meditate on it, and indeed I make good preparations; everyone who had a need has not gone without a profound bond.' 'He is my profound bond,' said she, 'my only son.' 'I will obtain that then,' said Colmán, 'and that will be avenged upon Aena.'

Irish: ba fíor són. ro marb bachlach do muinntir Chluana ech Aena ocá thafunn as a ghort. ro gabad in bachlach oc Aena corro naidmed cét mbó ar in mbachlach i níc in eich. táinic in bachlach ar sin co Colmán dá faighde. “gab in rannsa do Aena” ar Colmán.
English: And that was true: for a certain churl of the familia of Clonmacnoise chasing Aena’s horse out of his field killed him, and Aena, after having said churl seized, in satisfaction of the horse laid on him a fine of one hundred cows; whereupon the common fellow for comfort repairing to Colmán, the king said: “to Aena recite this quatrain.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: That was true. A churl of Cluain's people killed Aena's horse while chasing it from his field. The churl was captured by Aena, and a hundred cows were imposed on the churl as compensation for the horse. Thereupon, the churl came to Colmán to seek his help. 'Take this portion to Aena,' said Colmán.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: That was true. A churl from Cluain's people killed Aena's horse while chasing it out of his field. Aena captured the churl, and a hundred cows were imposed on the churl as compensation for the horse. Thereupon, the churl came to Colmán to ask for his help. 'Take this portion to Aena,' said Colmán.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: That was true. A churl of the people of Clonmacnoise killed Aena's horse while chasing it out of his field. The churl was captured by Aena, and a hundred cows were imposed on the churl as payment for the horse. The churl then came to Colmán to ask for his help. 'Take this portion to Aena,' said Colmán.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: That was true. A churl of Cluana's people killed Aena's horse while chasing it from his field. The churl was seized by Aena, and a hundred cows were demanded from the churl as compensation for the horse. The churl then came to Colmán to ask for his help. 'Take this verse to Aena,' said Colmán.

Irish: tánaic in bachlach reime co hAena ocus do gab in rann .i. Tháinig fear an ghoirt roimhe chun Aena agus do ghabh sé an rann: “Do mac Laígse ba mór gó . in aenchenn ar in cét mbó; in mór do dul ar in mbec . in fubann in tsacairbec” “Is fuba imorro” ol Aena: “ní iarrubsa fortsa acht aenbhó.” ro búi dana a leithéite sin co meinic itir Aena ocus Colmán.
English: The churl came to Aena, and delivered the quatrain:— “Great falsehood [i.e. an iniquitous award] it was for mac Laígse that a single head [i.e. one animal] should be made to represent an hundred kine; that the much should pass in payment for the little *does that impair the sacred host (i.e. vitiate thy sacred profession)?”*“Verily,” Aena said, “it is an iniquity, and I will ask of thee but one cow.” Now this kind of thing often passed between Colmán and him.
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The churl came onward to Aena and recited the verse, namely: “To the son of Laígse, it was a great wrong: one head for a hundred cows; the great to go on the small; is the small sacrifice a burden?” “It is indeed a burden,” said Aena: “I will not ask of you but one cow.” Such a thing occurred frequently between Aena and Colmán.
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The churl came forward to Aena and recited the verse: 'To the son of Laígse it was a great injustice: one head for a hundred cows; the great to go on the small; is it a shame, the little priest?' 'It is indeed a shame,' said Aena, 'I will not ask of you but one cow.' Such a thing often happened between Aena and Colmán.
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The churl came before Aena and recited the verse, namely: “To the son of Laigse, it was a great wonder: the single head for the hundred cows; the great to go on the small. Is the small offering a trick?” “It is indeed a trick,” said Aena, “I will ask of you only one cow.” Such things often occurred between Aena and Colmán.
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The churl came forward to Aena and sang the verse: 'To the son of Laígse it was a great wrong: one head for a hundred cows; the great to burden the small; is it fitting, the little priest?' 'It is fitting indeed,' said Aena: 'I will ask nothing of you but one cow.' And such a thing was often between Aena and Colmán.

Irish: Fecht ann, bae Óengus ic fothrucud hi tich Aithechdai ocus bae for menmain dó-side a marbad-som. (Ní bae dano Dubchrón gilla Óengus ann in tan-sin.) Mus léc fer díb aigen láin gríscha moa súili ocus moa aigid ocus clannaid Athechda a gae fodessin ind (.i. in Charr Óengus) co mbaí triit conarro marbsat samlaid. Benait iarom a chenn de ocus do·berar hé for a dérgud ocus bratt dar a chenn. Do·rooig Dubchrón for Dubglais .i. for a gabair-seom. “Tairling, a Dubchróin,” ar cách. “Níthó,” ar Dubchrón. “Cate Óengus?” “A·tá inna chotlud; sit, sit, ar nácha ndúsca. Tairling ocus tair ’sin tech.” “Ní dóig limm a chotlud acht má beind-se coa aire. Gataid in mbratt dia aigid,” ar se. Gattair de. “Fír, a Óengus ,” ar sé. Ocus dixit: “Deithbir dond aigid cid bán cond·ránic fri faeburdán; imma·rulaid ilar lám in cenn fil for Óengus.”
English: Another time Óengus was bathing in the house of Aithechda and it was in Aithechda’s mind to kill him. *However* Dubchrón, Óengus’s servant, was not there on this occasion. One of the men present quickly tipped a pan *full* of embers into the eyes *and face* of Óengus and Aithechda thrust Óengus’s own spear into him *so that it went through him* and so killed him. Then, they stuck off his head and placed him on a bed with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón arrived on Dubglas, Óengus’s horse. “Get down, Dubchrón,” they all said. “No,” he replied, “Where is Óengus?” “Hush, *hush,* he is asleep — do not disturb him. Dismount and come over into the house.” “It is not likely that Óengus would rest unless I were watching over him. Remove the cloak from his face.” It was removed. “So it is true, Óengus,” he said: “Though it is white it befits the face, that has met with swordplay. The head of Óengus has passed through many hands.”
gemini_T0.1_K30_P0.7: One time, Óengus was bathing in Aithechda's house, and Aithechda intended to kill him. (Dubchrón, Óengus's servant, was not there at that time.) One of the men threw a basin full of embers into his eyes and onto his face, and Aithechda thrust his own spear, Óengus's Charr, into him so that it went through him, and they killed him thus. Then they cut off his head and he was placed on his bed with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón arrived on Dubglais, his horse. 'Dismount, O Dubchrón,' said everyone. 'No indeed,' said Dubchrón. 'Where is Óengus?' 'He is asleep; hush, hush, lest you wake him. Dismount and come into the house.' 'I do not think he is asleep, unless I were watching him. Take the cloak from his face,' said he. It was taken from him. 'True, O Óengus,' said he. And he said: 'It is natural for the face to be pale, since it met with a sharp weapon; many hands have dealt with the head that is on Óengus.'
gemini_T0.2_K40_P0.85: One time, Óengus was bathing in Aithechda's house, and Aithechda intended to kill him. (Óengus's servant Dubchrón was not there at that time.) Then they cut off his head and he was placed on his bed with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón arrived on Dubglais, that is, on his horse. 'Dismount, Dubchrón,' everyone said. 'No,' said Dubchrón. 'Where is Óengus?' 'He is asleep; hush, hush, lest you wake him. Dismount and come into the house.' 'I do not think he is asleep unless I were watching him. Take the cloak from his face,' he said. It was taken from him. 'Indeed, Óengus,' he said. And he said: 'It is fitting for the face to be pale since it met with a sharp weapon; many hands have passed over the head that is on Óengus.'
gemini_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Once, Óengus was bathing in Aithechda's house, and Aithechda intended to kill him. (Óengus's servant Dubchrón was not there at that time.) One of the men threw a basin full of glowing embers into his eyes and onto his face, and Aithechda thrust Óengus's own spear (the Charr) into him, so that it went through him, and they killed him thus. Then they struck off his head, and he was placed on his bed with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón rode on Dubglas, that is, on his horse. 'Dismount, Dubchrón,' said everyone. 'No,' said Dubchrón. 'Where is Óengus?' 'He is asleep; hush, hush, lest you wake him. Dismount and come into the house.' 'I do not think he is asleep unless I am watching him. Take the cloak from his face,' he said. It was taken from him. 'True, Óengus,' he said. And he said: 'It is fitting for the face, though pale, that it met with a sharp weapon; many hands have been laid upon Óengus's head.'
gemini_T1.0_K40_P0.9: One time, Óengus was bathing in Aithechda's house, and it was in Aithechda's mind to kill him. (Óengus's servant, Dubchrón, was not there at that time.) One of the men threw a basin full of embers onto his eyes and face, and Aithechda plunged his own spear into him (namely, Óengus's Charr), so that it went through him, and they killed him thus. They then cut off his head, and he was placed on his couch with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón rode upon Dubglais, that is, his horse. 'Dismount, Dubchrón,' everyone said. 'No indeed,' said Dubchrón. 'Where is Óengus?' 'He is asleep; peace, peace, lest you wake him. Dismount and come into the house.' 'I do not think he is asleep, unless I were guarding him. Remove the cloak from his face,' said he. It was removed from him. 'True, Óengus,' he said. And he said: 'It is fitting for the face to be pale, since it met with a sharp weapon; many hands have dealt with the head that is on Óengus.'
